title: SALUTATIONS!
text:
My name is Rebecca.


I am an engineer and movement enthusiast, but most of all, an educator. I am passionate about sharing my knowledge, whether it be about computers or movement. I find satisfaction in lifting others up and leaving every space I occupy in a better state than I found it. My two favorite things are handstands and rabbits üê∞



Engineering Movement Education Creativity

title: SPOILER ALERT!
text:
How to view the worksheet answers
The Computer Systems and Assembly Language worksheet answers are hidden in the Google Doc style Heading 4. Follow these instructions to view the hidden text.

Make a copy of the worksheet and save to your Google Drive. 
Select some answer text. 
Change the text color.  
While the text is selected, change the color for Heading 4 by selecting Update 'Heading 4' to match. 
Now the answers are visible!

title: How To Learn
text:
Show up. Do the things. Be consistent.


A large part of making progress is just showing up ‚Äì even if you don‚Äôt feel like it.
In the case of academics, to increase the probability that you might learn something from lecture, come to class prepared. Bring:

Paper
A writing utensil
A notebook
Colored pens or highlighters

Be present in class; eliminate distractions by stashing your electronics.



Just ‚Äúdo the things,‚Äù i.e.¬†practice with intention.
My number #1 tip: Find a study group. How do you find a study group? Go to office hours and supplementary tutoring sessions if they are offered.
Review your notes after every class starting from the beginning of the quarter. Redo all of the examples, and complete any examples not covered in lecture.
Repetition is key to understanding. Spending time to strengthen your knowledge foundation will serve you in completing the lab assignments.
Start assignments early. You will inevitably run into bugs that you have to fix. This often takes way longer than you might think to resolve. Starting labs early enables you to catch these issues early on so you are not panicked at 11 pm on the due date.
Make up your own examples. Rewrite the homework with different numbers. Solve this new version of the homework.
If you feel that you‚Äôve been ‚Äúdoing the things‚Äù and you are still stuck, reflect upon the approach you are taking. Are you hitting roadblocks in your process? Talk to others to get their feedback and form a new plan.



The key to progression in any context is consistency. We can‚Äôt expect to learn a new subject or skill if we don‚Äôt work it into our weekly schedule. So, just show up and do the things. Consistently.

‚ÄúWe can determine how to be masters of our habits so that our habits may be useful servants to us.‚Äù

title: Computer Systems and Assembly Language
text:
I find magic in understanding a computer all the way down to its ones and zeros.
From 2018 to 2019, I had the joy of teaching Computer Systems and Assembly Language at the University of California, Santa Cruz. In this ‚Äúcomputer engineering 101‚Äù course, I restructured the curriculum and taught foundational concepts including binary, digital logic design, memory alignment, and assembly language.
My favorite topic to teach was data path where I guided students through how an assembly instruction breaks down into machine code and how those ones and zeros flow through the processor.
This page contains the course material from that class to serve as a reference for anyone interested, and as an example of my work in education, documentation, and curriculum design.

title: Computer Systems and Assembly Language
text:
Worksheets
I teach Computer Systems and Assembly language using fill-in-the-blank worksheets that I‚Äôve designed. Students who manually write out notes are more likely to retain information presented in class over students who type notes.
These worksheets allow students to handwrite notes and maintain better engagement in class, rather than losing focus by copying slides. I include examples for students to work out both during lecture with their classmates, and outside of class.



Notes  0: Intro To Computing Systems
  worksheet
  history of computing, computing levels of abstraction
  SUPPLEMENTS Who invented the computer?
  


Notes  1: Integer Numbering Systems
  worksheet
  unary, grouping, positional, decimal, octal, hexadecimal, binary
  SUPPLEMENTS Number Systems and Bases: Better Explained Introduction to number systems and binary: Khan Academy The Number Base Calculator: Cleave Books
  


Notes 2a: Combinational Logic 1
  worksheet
  MOSFET transistors, PMOS, NMOS, logic gates, inverter, and, or, nand, nor, xor, xnor, Venn diagrams
  SUPPLEMENTS CMOS Transistors: Peter Mathys (watch 13:05 - 17:00)
  


Notes 2b: Combinational Logic 2
  worksheet
  digital circuit examples, sum of products (SOP), product of sums (POS), minterms, maxterms, programmable logic array (PLA)
  SUPPLEMENTS Minterms, Maxterms, and Cannonical Boolean Expressions: EngMicroLectures SOP and POS: Peter Mathys
  


Notes 2c: Combinational Logic 3
  worksheet
  multiplexors, decoders, half adder, full adder, ripple-carry adder, ALU
  
  


Notes  3: Boolean Algebra
  worksheet
  Boolean identities, De Morgan's Law
  SUPPLEMENTS Boolean Algebra: electronics-course.com Boolean Algebra Example: Peter Mathys NAND/NOR Only Example: Peter Mathys
  


Notes  4: Sequential Logic
  worksheet
  SR latch, active high, active low, D latch, D flip-flop
  SUPPLEMENTS Timing Diagrams: EngMicroLectures SR Latches, D Latches, and D Flip-flops: EngMicroLectures SR Latch: Ben Eater SR Latch | NOR and NAND SR Latch: Neso Academy Registers, Flip-flops, and Modular Design: EngMicroLectures
  


Notes  5: Signed Integer Representation
  worksheet
  signed numbers, sign magnitude, two‚Äôs complement, bias / excess notation, floating point, fixed point
  SUPPLEMENTS Two's Complement: Negative Numbers in Binary: Ben Eater Computer Science Concepts: Bias-K/Excess-K: Atiwong Suchato
  


Notes  6: Arithmetic and Logic Operations
  worksheet
  carry out, overflow, bitwise, reduction, shifts, rotate
  SUPPLEMENTS Two's Complement Representation and Overflow: EngMicroLectures
  


Notes  7: Fractional Representation
  worksheet
  fixed point, IEEE 754 single precision floating point
  SUPPLEMENTS Binary Fractions: Electronics Tutorials
  


Notes  8: Text Representation
  worksheet
  ASCII, UTF-8
  
  


Notes  9: von Neumann Model
  worksheet
  von Neumann architecture, memory, address space, addressibility, processing unit, control unit, input, output, memory
  
  


Notes 10: MIPS Instruction Set Architecture
  worksheet
  general purpose registers, assembler directives, data directives, labels, instruction format, instruction types, operate instructions, data movement (loads and stores), control flow instructions, little endian, big endian, memory alignment, pseudo instructions, instruction encoding
  SUPPLEMENTS MIPS Reference Table: Rebecca Rashkin MIPS Instruction Format: Rebecca Rashkin Printable ASCII Characters: Rebecca Rashkin
  


Notes 11: MARS: MIPS Assembler and Runtime Simulator
  worksheet
  memory display, syscalls
  
  


Notes 12: MIPS Addressing Modes
  worksheet
  register direct, immediate, register indirect, base + offset (displacement), PC relative, pseudo direct
  
  


Notes 13: Stacks and Subroutines
  worksheet
  stack, jump instructions, return address, subroutines
  SUPPLEMENTS MIPS Videos: David Black-Schaffer (Videos 2.7 - 2.12)
  


Notes 14: MIPS Data Path
  worksheet
  mips data path, r-type, i-type, j-type, pc, register file, alu, control unit
  SUPPLEMENTS MIPS32 Data Path: Rebecca Rashkin
